newsitem.title: BELGIUM: NATO states approve deal with Russia.
newsitem.headline: NATO states approve deal with Russia.

text.p: NATO's 16 member states formally approved on Friday a landmark post-Cold War security accord with Russia, negotiated by Secretary General Javier Solana and Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov earlier this week.
The pact is intended to defuse Russian opposition to NATO's planned expansion into former communist states in Eastern Europe that once formed part of the Soviet bloc.
"The North Atlantic Council has given its approval to the Founding Act...between NATO and the the Russian Federation," an official communique said.
The accord was presented to NATO's ambassadors when Solana returned from Moscow on Wednesday, but national capitals were given 48 hours to object.
The communique confirmed the "Founding Act on Mutual Relations, Cooperation and Security between NATO and the Russia Federation" would be signed in Paris on May 27.
Russia has yet to adopt formally the accord which President Boris Yeltsin described on Thursday as "a really major step aimed at more stability in Europe and the world overall".
Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are likely to be invited to join the alliance at a special summit in Madrid on July 8-9, with Slovenia and Romania seen as possibles.
